key_insight: DVGT reconstructs a global dense 3D point map directly from sequences of unposed multi-view driving images by using a transformer to aggregate visual features across views and time, enabling robust dense geometry perception without requiring known camera poses.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap in driving-targeted dense geometry perception by providing a model that adapts to diverse driving scenarios and camera configurations and reconstructs dense 3D scene geometry from unposed, multi-view visual inputs.
method: Extract per-image mid/high-level features using a DINO backbone for robust, pose-agnostic visual representation.
Use a Visual Geometry Transformer to aggregate cross-view and temporal features, reasoning about correspondences and global geometry.
Decode fused features into a global dense 3D point map (point cloud) suitable for downstream driving tasks, with mechanisms to handle varying camera setups and unposed inputs.
impact: Enables scalable, pose-agnostic dense 3D perception for autonomous driving and mapping, reducing reliance on precise sensor calibration and improving adaptability across vehicles and camera rigs.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multi-view driving images → DINO feature extractor → Transformer fusion → global dense 3D point map output
Before/after comparison: sparse or pose-required reconstruction vs DVGT dense, pose-free reconstruction (side-by-side point clouds)
Illustration of transformer attention across time/views (arrows linking multiple cameras/frames to a unified geometry)
Robustness chart: reconstruction quality vs varying camera configurations / missing poses (small bar/line chart)
paper_authors: Sicheng Zuo, Zixun Xie, Wenzhao Zheng, Shaoqing Xu, Fang Li
